Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Development of microalgae for commercial hydrogen biofuels
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project proposes to use an innovative approach to metabolically engineer algae that will enable low-cost, carbon-free hydrogen production at medium to large scale. The metabolic pathway for hydrogen production in microalgae is tightly regulated. Process models for hydrogen production are based on anaerobic sulfur-deprivation preventing generation of oxygen, which inactivates hydrogenases. However, hydrogen yields are too low for an economical commercial process. Hydrogen production rates are difficult to improve due to complicated metabolic pathways guarding hydrogen production. Novel proprietary Chlamydomonas strains with synthetic genes for hydrogenase and maturation proteins were created and proven in Phase I. This project will continue the metabolic engineering to increase electron availability for hydrogenase and develop stable strains for scalable and commercially viable production of hydrogen. The proposed research will expand fundamental understanding of: 1) electron flow toward algal hydrogenases under sulfur-rich conditions and sulfur-deprivation, 2) requirements for maturation of hydrogenases, and 3) requirements to protect hydrogenases from oxygen.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project, if successful, will be the commercial generation of cost-effective, renewable, and environmentally clean hydrogen that could greatly impact the nation's ability to reduce its use of foreign oil and create many new jobs. The commercial hydrogen production currently is burdened by major dependence on electricity and carbon dioxide emission. The proposed approach provides a commercial process for hydrogen production that will generate electricity and sequester carbon dioxide. The abundance of low-cost, renewable hydrogen should expand hydrogen markets to generate electricity and fuel vehicles. Just 200,000 ha of algal ponds using improved strains could displace 20% of imported crude oil. Thus, the project will have great commercial impact by enhancing national energy security. Moreover, this technology will promote diversification and sustainability of agricultural production in the U.S. through development of algae farming, which will not require arable land. Potentially, this technology will produce the most ecologically clean biofuel theoretically available, and could have great social impact by decreasing the carbon footprint and promoting economic diversification in rural areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this NSF-funded  SBIR Phase II project, BHO  has successfully developed advanced, metabolically-engineered, algae with generation rates suitable for commercial production of hydrogen. An innovative approach was implemented for synthetic gene engineering which resulted in both improved gene stability and function. When fully developed, this technology will bring this 3rd generation clean fuel from the future into the present. Hydrogen can be efficiently used as clean transportation or heating fuel or converted to electricity with numerous additional  uses by the food, chemical and pharmaceutical industries.

 Annual CO2 emissions by U.S. power facilities now exceed 2,000 million metric tons. In addition, nearly 8,500 million metric tons of natural gas (methane) are produced annually in U.S. Methane is nearly 500 times more destructive  for the ozone layer than CO2.  This innovative technology will have ZERO CO2 footprint, with no methane releases and with the added benefits of  producing clean algal biomass with valuable nutrition and chemical properties.

 Green microalgae are known to produce hydrogen using sunlight and water. Process models for hydrogen production are based on anaerobic sulfur-deprivation to prevent the generation of oxygen, which activates hydrogenases. However, to date, hydrogen yields have been far too low to make this economical commercial process. Metabolic pathways for hydrogen production in microalgae are tightly regulated. Thus, hydrogen production rates are difficult to improve due to the complexity  of the important metabolic pathways and specifically gene regulation regarding hydrogen production.

 Critical milestones were achieved during Phase II leading to the determination that high-rate H2 production is possible. Metabolically engineered strains with greatly increased hydrogen  yields were created which demonstrated improved long-term stability of synthetic genes. For this, several genes were identified, with aid of metabolic modeling, and investigated to determine those requirements for boosting hydrogen formation in algae. Novel proprietary genes used in  metabolic engineering for the production of Chlamydomonas strains were created. Synthetic, proprietary genes for chimeric hydrogenases and proteins from the hydrogen metabolic pathway were introduced in algae which greatly boosted hydrogen yields.    

  A pilot production system for evaluating  hydrogen production was assembled and employed in the investigations. Additional work planned is expected to reveal further refinements for optimizing  continuous hydrogen production processes.  Prerequisites for commercial operations were established by the end of Phase II which culminated in demonstrating the feasibility of developing a large scale commercial process for hydrogen production using BHO’s proprietary production strains. Two (2) highly effective methods for hydrogen purification from algal bioreactors were identified. Both methods can operate at ambient temperature, low pressure with low concentrations of H2 in the feed gas. Specifications, and limited engineering design for an easily scalable hydrogen production plant were generated.
